repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Early Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Emergency Early
            Recovery Project (EERP) for Congo was satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the borrower performance was highly
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: The success
            of EERP confirms both post conflict intervention theory and
            practice in other countries (in particular the Balkans). The
            project corroborates the relevance of a flexible strategic
            and programmatic approach. The ring-fenced approach has both
            positive and negative aspects. The project demonstrates that
            it is worthwhile to take measured risks. The project also
            demonstrates the benefits of having a locally-based task
            team leader, in a context such as Democratic Republic of
            Congo (DRC). Some of the difficulties of the project reveal
            that communication with local population is crucial.
            Government implementing agencies also highlighted the need
            to have funding available for performance-based premium for
            civil servants involved in project implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Early Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Early Recovery Project
            will finance a limited set of priority activities that will
            provide the backbone of the assistance needed in the first
            phase of the Transition Support Strategy (TSS). In
            particular, the project will assist the government to a)
            strengthen institutional capacity and formulate economic
            policy, and b) address urgent needs and pilot implementation
            solutions. In terms of strengthening institutional capacity
            and formulating economic policy, the capacity building for
            management of donor assistance component will assist the
            government in building capacity to manage external
            assistance, so as to prepare the ground for the recovery
            phase during which levels of external assistance are
            expected to be large. The support to good governance and
            economic management component will address priority capacity
            building and technical assistance needs in the next twelve
            months. To address urgent needs and piloting implementation
            solutions, the HIV/AIDS component will finance a scale-up of
            activities using those agencies that already have a track
            record of successful implementation in the respective areas.
            The community driven development pilot fund will support
            community driven development activities in rural areas. The
            infrastructure component will focus on only one road which
            have the most potential for immediate impact on the
            livelihood of a large part of the population. The
            unallocated US$3 million will be kept for flexible use.
